title: What causes the phases of the moon?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we see different phases of the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth's rotation causes the moon to change shape.

options.label: B
options.text: The Sun's light is blocked by the Earth, causing the moon to be dark.

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's perspective on the moon changes as it moves around the Sun.

options.label: D
options.text: The moon's orbit is tilted at an angle to the Earth's orbit.

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't the Earth block the light when we see a full moon?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon is in the opposite side of the Earth from the Sun.

options.label: B
options.text: The Earth's shadow is too small to block the light.

options.label: C
options.text: The moon's orbit is tilted slightly to the Earth's orbit.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere is too thin to block the light.

multiple-choice.question: What causes a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth passes in front of the Sun, blocking its light.

options.label: B
options.text: The Moon passes through the Earth's shadow.

options.label: C
options.text: The Sun passes behind the Earth, blocking its light.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere scatters the light, making the moon appear red.

multiple-choice.question: Why is a lunar eclipse important to us?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to see the Earth's atmosphere in detail.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us understand the Earth's rotation and moon's orbits.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us detect the presence of life on other planets.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a rare and spectacular astronomical event.

multiple-choice.question: What can we learn from observing the light reflected off the moon during a lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: The composition of the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: The temperature of the moon's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of water vapor and other gases in an exoplanet's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: The speed of the Earth's rotation.

title: Myths you learned in health class

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem with the original food pyramid introduced in 1992?

options.label: A
options.text: It emphasized the importance of eating fruits and vegetables.

options.label: B
options.text: It failed to separate healthy whole grains from refined grains.

options.label: C
options.text: It recommended eating too much red meat.

options.label: D
options.text: It did not provide enough servings of dairy products.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the US Department of Agriculture create the original food pyramid?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote the health and well-being of Americans.

options.label: B
options.text: To confuse and mislead the public about nutrition.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote the food industry and the interests of food manufacturers.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a simple and easy-to-follow guide to healthy eating.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with relying solely on exercise for weight loss?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not effective for burning calories.

options.label: B
options.text: It can make you hungry and more likely to reach for unhealthy snacks.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only effective for people who are already fit and healthy.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to overexertion and injury.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the "My Plate" dietary guide introduced in 2011?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a simple and easy-to-follow guide to healthy eating.

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasizes the importance of eating a variety of different foods.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a more accurate and up-to-date guide to nutrition than the original food pyramid.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only suitable for people who are already healthy and fit.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important for students to learn about the myths and misconceptions surrounding nutrition and exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: So they can memorize outdated science and pass a test.

options.label: B
options.text: So they can develop healthy nutritional choices and exercise routines that they can stick with.

options.label: C
options.text: So they can become experts in nutrition and fitness.

options.label: D
options.text: So they can ignore the advice of health experts and make their own decisions about nutrition and exercise.

title: How well do masks work?

multiple-choice.question: How are COVID-19 viruses spread?

options.label: A
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person.

options.label: B
options.text: Through contaminated surfaces.

options.label: C
options.text: Through air currents, carrying microscopic droplets full of coronavirus.

options.label: D
options.text: Through contaminated food and water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of wearing a mask during the COVID-19 pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep you from getting sick.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep you from getting others sick.

options.label: C
options.text: To protect your face from the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: To make a fashion statement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the imaging technique used to visualize airflow and droplets in the air?

options.label: A
options.text: Schlieren imaging.

options.label: B
options.text: X-ray imaging.

options.label: C
options.text: MRI imaging.

options.label: D
options.text: CT scan imaging.

multiple-choice.question: Why do masks help to slow the spread of airborne infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they filter out all viral particles.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they trap larger droplets of moisture that contain viruses.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they disperse air currents, making it harder for droplets to travel far.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they make the air inside the mask too hot and humid.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important question to ask when it comes to wearing a mask during the COVID-19 pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: Will it protect me from getting sick?

options.label: B
options.text: Will it make me look cool?

options.label: C
options.text: Will it stop the pandemic on its own?

options.label: D
options.text: Will it send a message that we're all in this together?

title: Am I Really A Visual Learner?

multiple-choice.question: What do researchers believe about the idea of learning styles?

options.label: A
options.text: They are an inherent trait that affects how well students learn.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a preference that can be influenced by the presentation format.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not important in determining how well students learn.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only relevant for students with a strong visual learning style.

multiple-choice.question: What did a 2008 review find about the study on learning styles?

options.label: A
options.text: It found that students learned best with their preferred style.

options.label: B
options.text: It found that students learned best with a combination of visual and verbal presentation formats.

options.label: C
options.text: It found that only one study supported the idea of learning styles, but it had significant flaws.

options.label: D
options.text: It found that learning styles were not important in determining how well students learn.

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers find in a study where students were taught basic physics and chemistry concepts?

options.label: A
options.text: Students learned better with plain text than with pictures.

options.label: B
options.text: Students learned better with pictures than with plain text.

options.label: C
options.text: Students learned equally well with both plain text and pictures.

options.label: D
options.text: Students learned worse with pictures than with plain text.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the idea that people have different ways of learning, such as visual or verbal learning?

options.label: A
options.text: Learning styles

options.label: B
options.text: Presentation formats

options.label: C
options.text: Learning preferences

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive abilities

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers find in a study where students were shown lists of words?

options.label: A
options.text: Students learned better when they only heard the words.

options.label: B
options.text: Students learned better when they only saw the words.

options.label: C
options.text: Students learned better when they saw the words in print.

options.label: D
options.text: Students learned equally well with all three presentation formats.

title: Is binge watching bad for you?

options.text: They caused eye strain and sore eyes, but were generally short-term effects.

options.label: B
options.text: They were completely safe and had no negative effects on humans.

options.label: C
options.text: They were deadly and led to a significant number of fatalities.

options.label: D
options.text: They were only slightly harmful and caused minor health issues.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It may increase the risk of sleep disorders.

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: Why does smoke follow you around a fire?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why smoke keeps blowing in your face when you're sitting by a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the fire is too hot and the air can't handle it.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air around you is too dense and can't move.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the rising air is pushed by the air around it, creating a vacuum that brings smoke towards you.

options.label: D
options.text: Because you're cursed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the movement of hot air rising and being replaced by cooler air?

options.label: A
options.text: Conduction

options.label: B
options.text: Convection

options.label: C
options.text: Radiation

options.label: D
options.text: Diffusion

multiple-choice.question: Why does the hot air around a fire rise into the sky?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's less dense than the air around it and gravity pulls it down less.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's more dense than the air around it and gravity pulls it down more.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's hotter than the air around it and it expands.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's colder than the air around it and it contracts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of having more people in one place when sitting by a fire?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the amount of smoke that blows towards you.

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the amount of smoke that blows towards you.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the amount of smoke that blows towards you because more people block more of the airflow.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the fire burn more efficiently.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea behind smokeless fire pits?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a special type of wood that doesn't produce smoke.

options.label: B
options.text: They create additional paths for incoming air, reducing or eliminating how much smoke a fire produces.

options.label: C
options.text: They use a fan to blow the smoke away from the fire.

options.label: D
options.text: They use a special type of fuel that burns completely, producing no smoke.

title: Does aloe vera really treat a sunburn?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why humans have been using aloe vera medicinally for thousands of years?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to its antibacterial and antifungal properties.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has skin-healing properties.

options.label: C
options.text: For its anti-inflammatory effects.

options.label: D
options.text: To treat various medical conditions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern when treating burns, and how does aloe vera address it?

options.label: A
options.text: Reducing pain, and aloe vera does this by reducing inflammation.

options.label: B
options.text: Healing the wound, and aloe vera does this by stimulating the production of fibroblastic growth factor.

options.label: C
options.text: Preventing infection, and aloe vera does this by its antibacterial and antifungal activities.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the enzyme in aloe that breaks down bradykinin, an inflammatory substance linked with pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucomannan

options.label: B
options.text: Fibroblastic growth factor

options.label: C
options.text: Bradykininase

options.label: D
options.text: Mannose

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of glucomannan in aloe vera, and how does it affect skin healing?

options.label: A
options.text: It stimulates the production of fibroblastic growth factor, which helps speed up skin healing.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces inflammation, which helps reduce pain.

options.label: C
options.text: It prevents infection by its antibacterial and antifungal activities.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on skin healing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of human studies on the effectiveness of aloe vera in treating burns?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all large-scale studies.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all high-quality studies.

options.label: C
options.text: They are all small-scale studies with potentially biased results.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all animal studies on animals.

title: The physics of a pool vortex

multiple-choice.question: What is a vortex?

options.label: A
options.text: A gas or liquid moving in a straight line.

options.label: B
options.text: A gas or liquid moving in circles with a vortex line going up through the circles.

options.label: C
options.text: A wave that transfers energy but doesn't transfer matter.

options.label: D
options.text: A disturbance that occurs when two media meet.

multiple-choice.question: Why do vortices form when a plate is dragged through the water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the difference in fluid speed between the plate and the surrounding water.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the friction between the plate and the water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the wind blowing over the water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the sun shining on the water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the shape of the vortex line when a plate is dragged through the water?

options.label: A
options.text: A straight line.

options.label: B
options.text: A curved line.

options.label: C
options.text: A loop.

options.label: D
options.text: A spiral.

multiple-choice.question: Why do the dark spots form when a vortex is created in the water?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the sunlight shining on the water.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the balance between gravity, centripetal forces, and surface tension.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the friction between the plate and the water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the wind blowing over the water.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't a vortex line start or end in a fluid?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the difference in fluid speed between the plate and the surrounding water.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the friction between the plate and the water.

options.label: C
options.text: According to Helmholtz's law, a vortex line cannot start or end in a fluid.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the wind blowing over the water.

title: The fascinating physics of boat wakes

multiple-choice.question: What is unusual about the wake behind a duck, a kayak, or a ship?

options.label: A
options.text: The wake is simple and straight.

options.label: B
options.text: The wake is a feathery, ripple-y pattern.

options.label: C
options.text: The wake is only visible in calm water.

options.label: D
options.text: The wake is only visible in rough water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason water waves always have a particular shape and pattern?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the speed of light waves.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the speed of sound waves.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the phenomenon of dispersion.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the shape of the boat.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a boat travels across water waves of a single wavelength?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a V-shaped wake.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a circular wave that encircles the boat.

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a series of circular waves that add together to create a V-shaped wake.

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a train of V-shaped wakes that are each exactly one wavelength apart.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of dispersion on water waves?

options.label: A
options.text: Different wavelengths travel at the same speed.

options.label: B
options.text: Different wavelengths travel at different speeds, with longer waves traveling faster and shorter waves traveling slower.

options.label: C
options.text: Different wavelengths have the same amplitude.

options.label: D
options.text: Different wavelengths have the same frequency.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of adding together narrow, closely spaced wakes and wider, more widely spaced wakes?

options.label: A
options.text: A simple, straight wake.

options.label: B
options.text: A feathery, ripple-y pattern that looks like a boat wake.

options.label: C
options.text: A train of V-shaped wakes that are each exactly one wavelength apart.

options.label: D
options.text: A series of circular waves that add together to create a V-shaped wake.

options.label: B

title: The importance of a breakdown

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason people break down, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too stressed and overwhelmed.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not meeting the expectations of others.

options.label: C
options.text: They are attempting to force their minds into a process of growth, self-understanding, and self-development.

options.label: D
options.text: They are experiencing a random piece of madness or malfunction.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often try to medicalize a breakdown and attempt to shift it away, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they want to avoid the pain and discomfort associated with a breakdown.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are afraid of the unknown and the potential consequences of a breakdown.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are reluctant to engage with the emotional needs and demands of their minds.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they want to get back to business as usual as quickly as possible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker comparing the process of a breakdown to?

options.label: A
options.text: A vacation from reality.

options.label: B
options.text: A revolution.

options.label: C
options.text: A game of hide and seek.

options.label: D
options.text: A walk in the park.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of a breakdown, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To escape from reality and avoid dealing with one's problems.

options.label: B
options.text: To rebuild one's life on a more authentic and sincere basis.

options.label: C
options.text: To get back to business as usual as quickly as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: To become ill and stay that way.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often wonder if they have gone mad during a breakdown, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are experiencing a random piece of madness or malfunction.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are on a hidden yet logical search for health.

options.label: C
